The command name is what allows you to distinguish a command from another. For example the command with \'command name = MOVE\' will be responsible for sending a signal to move a motor. Also using a single character as a command name is considered to be a good practice since it takes less transfer time and can be handled easily.
Parameters:
Command name:

There are two types of parameters:\n constant parameters: are meant to be used by the developer as flags. You can use the same command name for different commands and use flags to distinguish between them.\n variable parameters: the number of variable parameters depends on the widget that will be linked to it. For example a Slider widget requires a single variable parameter for sending its variable value.
Manage your projects, create, access and edit your amazing GUIs !
Connect to your micro-controller via Bluetooth, UART or even TCP/IP
Test your connection and debug your program using the built-in Terminal

WARNING: Changing the number of variable parameters will force the widget linked to this command to reset to its default command.
An accelerometer block sends the acceleration on X Y and Z axis as FLOAT, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 3 variable parameters to insert the 3 FLOAT values in them.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) in your code to read the X Y or Z parameters correctly
A gyro block sends the rate of rotation around X Y and Z axis as FLOAT, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 3 variable parameters to insert the 3 FLOAT values in them.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) in your code to read the X Y or Z parameters correctly

An orientation block sends the orientation of the device (azimuth, pitch and roll) as FLOATs, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 3 variable parameters to insert the 3 FLOAT values in them.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) in your code to read the azimuth, pitch and roll parameters correctly
A gravity block sends the force of gravity along X Y and Z axis as FLOAT, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 3 variable parameters to insert the 3 FLOAT values in them.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) in your code to read the X Y or Z parameters correctly

A magnetic field block sends the geomagnetic field strength along X Y and Z axis as FLOAT, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 3 variable parameters to insert the 3 FLOAT values in them.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) in your code to read the X Y or Z parameters correctly

A proximity block sends a 1 when an object is close from the phone\'s proximity sensor (a couple of centimeters). An INTEGER value of 0 is sent otherwise, and all of this is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter. The value of proximity will be inserted in that variable parameter..

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) to read the value of the sensor
A light sensor block sends the Illuminance of the environment in lx as INTEGER, and that is based on the sampling period given by the user. The default sampling period is 100 000 us or 100ms
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter to insert the INTEGER value.
you should use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) in your code to read the Illuminance parameter correctly
A button simply sends a command when it is clicked
This widget requires a command that has 0 variable parameters.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you can use GCH_GetParamAsTYPE(&handle,index) to read the constant parameter in your commands (if any), the TYPE is the data type you intend to use for the parameter
A keypad widget sends a command when one of its buttons is clicked. The variable sent will be a character.
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameters.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you can use GCH_GetParamAsChar(&handle,index) to read the variable parameter
A slider widget has a thumb that can be dragged left or right. An INTEGER value between MIN and MAX will be sent when the slider progress is changed
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter. The progress of the slider will be inserted in the variable parameter whenever it is dragged.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) or GCH_GetParamAsLong(&handle,index)to read the progress of the slider
A knob widget send a progress value when it is turned clockwise and counterclockwise. An INTEGER value between 0 and MAX will be sent when the Knob is turned
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter to insert its progress into.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) or GCH_GetParamAsLong(&handle,index)to read the progress of the knob
A switch widget is toggled when it is clicked. An INTEGER value of either 0 or 1 will be sent when the switch is pressed
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter. The value of the switch will be inserted in that variable parameter whenever it is pressed.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) to read the value of the switch
A joystick sends the XY values of the thumb as INTEGERS. The XY values range between 0 and 1024
This widget requires a command that has 2 variable parameters to insert the XY values in them.
You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) to read the XY values
A touchpad sends the touch XY values as a percentage
This widget requires a command that has 2 variable parameters to insert the XY values in them.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsFloat(&handle,index) to read the XY values correctly
A Direction buttons widget sends the a character value depending on which one of the 4 buttons is clicked. The CHARACTER value can be \'U\', \'D\', \'L\', or \'R\'
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameter to insert the CHARACTER value in it.
You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsChar(&handle,index) to read the value correctly
A color picker widget sends the selected RGB value as a single INTEGER
This widget requires a command that has 1 variable parameters to insert the RGB value.

You should use GCH_GetStrCommandName(&handle,index) or GCH_GetCharCommandName(&handle,index) to read the command name. Also, you must use GCH_GetParamAsInt(&handle,index) to read the RGB value correctly

A Text display widget can be used to display some text sent from the connected device. The text sent to this widget must follow a specific format which will be discussed later in the \'usage section\'.
This widget requires a command that has 0 variable parameters. The Command Name will be used to identify this text display.

This widget doesn\'t need to be used with the app library. Instead the data that is sent to be displayed must follow a specific format. The format should be as follows: \">command_name,text......<\". The character \'>\' clears the previous text in the display and prepares it to receive new data. The character \'<\' is used to terminate the current text
A Text Edit widget can be used to send plain text to the connected device.
This widget does not use commands.
Since this widget sends plain text, it cannot be used with the app\'s library !
Checkout our YouTube playlist on how to use GuiConnect+ and get your project started
Open YouTube tutorials
Checkout our Helper library and its full documentation on Github
Open the helper library\'s github

Whether you're a professional, a student, a teacher, or a hobbyist, GuiConnect+ provides the quickest way to set up a graphical interface and wirelessly communicate with your microcontroller board regardless of platform (Arduino, ESP32, STM32â€¦).


GuiConnect+ turns your Android phone into an I/O device by allowing you to build highly customizable GUIs using drag-and-drop components. Custom commands allow you to customize the data that these components send, and you can connect to your embedded hardware via Bluetooth, UART, or TCP/IP. The app also gives you access to your smartphone's sensors and other features enabling amazing applications.


Finally, this app comes with a C library that handles data reception and parsing on the MCU side, allowing you to focus solely on the important aspects of your project !
